item.title: Two Italian priests martyred under Nazism in 1944 to be beatified
item.description:
Two young priests killed in Nazi reprisals in Italy's Emilia Romagna region are to be beatified, following decrees promulgated on Friday, which included four new Venerables from Italy, Australia, and Brazil.

Read all

item.title: Can industrial growth and climate action go hand in hand?
item.description: Do higher living standards in developing countries have to mean more polluting, fossil-fuel dependent industries? Or is a low-carbon alternative possible? As the world grapples with climate change, economic inequality, and rapid technological shifts, next week’s Global Industry Summit will tackle these questions, bringing together governments, business leaders, and innovators to shape solutions that balance prosperity with sustainability.
item.source:markdown: Do higher living standards in developing countries have to mean more polluting, fossil-fuel dependent industries? Or is a low-carbon alternative possible? As the world grapples with climate change, economic inequality, and rapid technological shifts, next week’s Global Industry Summit will tackle these questions, bringing together governments, business leaders, and innovators to shape solutions that balance prosperity with sustainability.

item.title: Gaza: Two children killed every day during fragile ceasefire, says UNICEF
item.description: Ongoing attacks and airstrikes attributed to Israeli forces in Gaza continue to kill and maim people of all ages in the shattered enclave despite an agreed ceasefire, UN agencies said on Friday.
item.source:markdown: Ongoing attacks and airstrikes attributed to Israeli forces in Gaza continue to kill and maim people of all ages in the shattered enclave despite an agreed ceasefire, UN agencies said on Friday.

item.title: It’s time for leadership and vision, Guterres tells G20 in South Africa
item.description: A South African flag-coloured King Protea flower – symbolising hope and regeneration – is the chosen logo for this year’s G20 Leaders’ Summit, taking place on African soil for the first time.
item.source:markdown: A South African flag-coloured King Protea flower – symbolising hope and regeneration – is the chosen logo for this year’s G20 Leaders’ Summit, taking place on African soil for the first time.

item.title: UN presents UN80 Initiative Action Plan, setting coordinated path for system-wide reforms
item.description: The United Nations outlined how it intends to advance one of its most comprehensive system-wide reform efforts in decades, as Under-Secretary-General for Policy Guy Ryder presented the UN80 Initiative Action Plan. The plan brings the Secretary-General’s major UN80 reform proposals into a single, coherent structure to streamline efforts that will make the UN system deliver better.
item.source:markdown: The United Nations outlined how it intends to advance one of its most comprehensive system-wide reform efforts in decades, as Under-Secretary-General for Policy Guy Ryder presented the UN80 Initiative Action Plan. The plan brings the Secretary-General’s major UN80 reform proposals into a single, coherent structure to streamline efforts that will make the UN system deliver better.

item.title: UN decries ‘truly horrific’ massacres in DR Congo
item.description: Seventeen civilians, including women in labour and patients receiving care, were slaughtered inside a Catholic Church-run health centre in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) last week.
item.source:markdown: Seventeen civilians, including women in labour and patients receiving care, were slaughtered inside a Catholic Church-run health centre in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) last week.

item.title: From waste pickers to courtrooms: Women demand a gender focus at COP30
item.description: On the scheduled final day of COP30 in Belém, tense negotiations are stretching into Friday afternoon as divisions persist. Amid the ongoing talks, one message is cutting through the noise: there is no climate justice without gender equality.
item.source:markdown: On the scheduled final day of COP30 in Belém, tense negotiations are stretching into Friday afternoon as divisions persist. Amid the ongoing talks, one message is cutting through the noise: there is no climate justice without gender equality.

item.title: Pope Leo consolidates governance reform for Vatican City Commission
item.description:
With a Motu Proprio, Pope Leo XIV has abrogated Article 8 n. 1 of the previous Fundamental Law of Vatican City State, which had allowed only cardinals to serve as president of the Commission, a position currently held by Sister Raffaella Petrini. The Pope, therefore, consolidates a change wanted by Francis and resolves an issue that had emerged due to increasingly “complex and pressing” governance needs.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
With a Motu Proprio, Pope Leo XIV has abrogated Article 8 n. 1 of the previous Fundamental Law of Vatican City State, which had allowed only cardinals to serve as president of the Commission, a position currently held by Sister Raffaella Petrini. The Pope, therefore, consolidates a change wanted by Francis and resolves an issue that had emerged due to increasingly “complex and pressing” governance needs.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-11/pope-leo-xiv-motu-proprio-presidency-vatican-city-commission.html)

item.description:
The Maronite Archbishop of Beirut, Paul Abdel Sater, looks forward to Pope Leo XIV's upcoming visit to Lebanon. He upholds the Pope's continuing closeness to the country and says his mere presence will provide huge encouragement to the population.

item.title: 60 years of Nostra Aetate: from a seed of hope a great tree has grown
item.description:
Participants from numerous countries and various religious traditions gathered at the international symposium "Nostra Aetate: 60 Years Later" held at the Pontifical University of the Holy Cross in Rome. Cardinal George Koovakad, Prefect of the Dicastery for Interreligious Dialogue and one of the speakers, emphasized that interreligious dialogue must receive greater attention on the international stage and that the spirit of Nostra Aetate remains essential for contemporary peacebuilding efforts.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Zelenskyy says Ukraine may face 'very difficult choice' as U.S. gives deadline on peace plan
item.description: Ukraine may face a hard choice at a pivotal point in its almost four-year fight to defeat Russia's full-scale invasion, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told Ukrainians in a national address Friday, pledging to hold constructive discussions with Washington on a U.S. peace proposal in what he called "truly one of the most difficult moments in our history."
item.source:markdown:
![A bearded man shakes hands in an ornate room with a taller, clean shaven man in suit and tie.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/f4be52bc-1077-49e9-a0c6-619f4c83b9f5,1763740641894/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C226%2C3000%2C1687%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Ukraine may face a hard choice at a pivotal point in its almost four-year fight to defeat Russia's full-scale invasion, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told Ukrainians in a national address Friday, pledging to hold constructive discussions with Washington on a U.S. peace proposal in what he called "truly one of the most difficult moments in our history."

item.title: Pope: Truth, justice, mercy essential in marital nullity reform
item.description:
Ten years after Pope Francis introduced a reform on marital nullity, Pope Leo XIV addresses members of a training course organized by the Roman Rota, urging them to discover the three dimensions of the marital process and how its end goal must always be the salvation of souls.

item.title: What are Russia's 'research vessels' off UK coast?

item.title: Pilot killed as Indian fighter jet crashes at Dubai Air Show
item.description: An Indian HAL Tejas crashed Friday local time while flying a demonstration flight for a crowd at the Dubai Air Show, sending black smoke over the Maktoum International Airport in the Emirates. It wasn't immediately clear if the pilot ejected the aircraft.
item.source:markdown:
![Fire fighters in uniforms, about four, are shown near a pile of wreckage on dirt ground. Some of them employ hoses to spray on the wreckage.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/0188f7d6-f1a3-4937-b303-742643b4e250,1763727133204/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C2030%2C1141%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Mexico City plans exhumation of 6,600 bodies in search for disappeared
item.description: Mexico City began a project this week to exhume and identify thousands of bodies from an area of common graves in a municipal cemetery as part of a multi-agency strategy to deal with its growing list of people registered as disappeared.

item.title: Why Canada is winning the travel trade war with the U.S.
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump’s divisive politics, tariffs and heightened border security have helped drive a decline in international tourism spending in the U.S. Meanwhile, polls and industry experts suggest a surge of Canadian patriotism and perceptions of Canada as a safe and friendly destination helped drive a record-breaking summer for tourism in the country.
item.source:markdown:
![Air passengers at airport walk by Canadians flags. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/7e09d118-e088-4ce6-a58e-accc2d68ed46,1763588697710/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28512%2C676%2C3798%2C2136%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Talks at WRC over school secretary pensions break down
item.description: Talks at the Workplace Relations Commission aimed at resolving a pensions dispute involving school secretaries and caretakers have broken down. The negotiations ended this evening without agreement, and the workers' trade union, Fórsa, said it wants the matter to be referred to the Labour Court.

item.description: A 1940 self-portrait by famed Mexican artist Frida Kahlo sold Thursday for $54.7 million US ($77 million Cdn) at a New York art auction and became the top sale price for a work by any female artist.

item.title: Actor Kevin Spacey says he's living out of hotels after losing Hollywood roles
item.description: Several men accused Spacey of making unwanted sexual advances during the #MeToo movement. In an interview with The Telegraph, Spacey said the financial hardship that followed has left him without a permanent home. While none of the allegations were proven in court, Spacey says the allegations have kept Hollywood at bay.
item.source:markdown:
![a man in a black and white tuxedo looks down with a serious look on his face](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/c5e4cf3c-cfbe-4c55-8c73-ce79f0ccadf7,1763682883716/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C574%2C5499%2C3093%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Several men accused Spacey of making unwanted sexual advances during the #MeToo movement. In an interview with The Telegraph, Spacey said the financial hardship that followed has left him without a permanent home. While none of the allegations were proven in court, Spacey says the allegations have kept Hollywood at bay.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Spotlight on rising casualties in Ukraine
item.description: The Security Council is holding a rare open briefing on Ukraine following days of deadly attacks by Russia on civilian areas and amid a renewed US mission to Kyiv in search of a peace deal. With attacks on energy infrastructure soaring and civilian casualties climbing, Council members have demanded answers and action. Can the Council increase pressure on veto-wielding Moscow, secure better protection and aid for civilians, and push toward an elusive ceasefire? Follow live below, find full UN meetings coverage here; UN News app users can click here.

item.title: Security Council’s veto power is ‘poster child’ of global gridlock, says Baerbock

item.title: What’s at stake in the COP30 negotiations?
item.description: Talks at the COP30 climate summit in Belém, Brazil, were suspended on Thursday after a fire broke out in the venue, triggering evacuations that halted negotiations between more than 190 delegations. The summit was set to conclude Friday, and the disruption came at a critical moment as countries were locked in tense debates over fossil fuels and climate finance. The outcome of these talks is widely seen as a litmus test for turning decades of climate pledges into concrete action.
item.source:markdown: Talks at the COP30 climate summit in Belém, Brazil, were suspended on Thursday after a fire broke out in the venue, triggering evacuations that halted negotiations between more than 190 delegations. The summit was set to conclude Friday, and the disruption came at a critical moment as countries were locked in tense debates over fossil fuels and climate finance. The outcome of these talks is widely seen as a litmus test for turning decades of climate pledges into concrete action.

item.title: Commission eyes measures to boost supplementary pensions
item.description: The European Commission will propose measures to boost supplementary pensions amid concerns that a shrinking workforce and ageing populations will mean that national pensions will become stretched over time.
item.source:markdown: The European Commission will propose measures to boost supplementary pensions amid concerns that a shrinking workforce and ageing populations will mean that national pensions will become stretched over time.

item.title: Woman charged over threats made against Simon Harris
item.description: A 40-year-old woman has appeared in court charged with making threats to Tánaiste Simon Harris and his family.
item.source:markdown: A 40-year-old woman has appeared in court charged with making threats to Tánaiste Simon Harris and his family.

item.title: Deadly Israeli strikes in Gaza continue into Thursday, with 32 killed in past 24 hours
item.description: Israeli airstrikes killed five people and wounded 18 others in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip on Thursday, local health authorities said, after Hamas and Israel accused each other of violating an increasingly fragile six-week-old truce.
item.source:markdown:
![A young girl cries as another woman holds her in her arms.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/48346a19-3c92-471d-be2f-08e525c33b6d,1763646825046/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C317%2C5500%2C3093%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Israeli airstrikes killed five people and wounded 18 others in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip on Thursday, local health authorities said, after Hamas and Israel accused each other of violating an increasingly fragile six-week-old truce.

item.title: Ukraine: Archbishop of Ternopil asks for prayers after deadly bombing
item.description:
Following a massive Russian attack on the western Ukrainian city of Ternopil, Archbishop Teodor Martynyuk tells Vatican News about the Greek-Catholic Church’s immediate assistance to affected residents, and calls on the faithful to pray for Ukrainians enduring the pain of war.

item.title: Europe, Ukraine must be involved in U.S.-Russia peace plan circulating, European diplomats say
item.description: Ukraine and Europe must be consulted on any efforts to end Russia's invasion of its neighbour, top European diplomats said Thursday, as reports circulated about a U.S.-Russian proposal to end the war at a time when corruption allegations have rattled Ukraine's government.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman speaks to the media.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/49ec5069-adf9-4a54-b4c4-5b634d790bd7,1763641161790/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C166%2C3189%2C1793%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Ukraine and Europe must be consulted on any efforts to end Russia's invasion of its neighbour, top European diplomats said Thursday, as reports circulated about a U.S.-Russian proposal to end the war at a time when corruption allegations have rattled Ukraine's government.

item.title: Pope Leo XIV: Recognizing each other as brothers is antidote to all extremism
item.description:
The Vatican Publishing House (LEV) releases Pope Leo XIV’s new book, entitled “The Power of the Gospel: Christian Faith in 10 Words.” Edited by Lorenzo Fazzini, the book is a collection of the Pope’s interventions and speeches, along with an unpublished introduction, which we publish in full below.

item.title: U.S. ambassador resents meddling in foreign electoral politics, but Trump doesn't seem to mind doing so
item.description: Pete Hoekstra accused Canada of interfering in electoral politics south in the U.S. Wednesday night at an event in Ottawa. It was an interesting perspective given that the man who nominated him for a U.S. ambassador role, President Donald Trump, hasn't exactly been circumspect in talking about foreign elections.
item.source:markdown:
![A bald, older man is shown in extreme closeup, wearing a suit and tie and an American flag pin on his lapel.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/7d837ab5-90d2-44d8-82e2-38f4c9aa8b34,1763636640658/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C342%2C7426%2C4177%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Pete Hoekstra accused Canada of interfering in electoral politics south in the U.S. Wednesday night at an event in Ottawa. It was an interesting perspective given that the man who nominated him for a U.S. ambassador role, President Donald Trump, hasn't exactly been circumspect in talking about foreign elections.

item.title: Human Rights Watch accuses Israel of crimes in West Bank
item.description: Israel's expulsion of tens of thousands of Palestinians from three Occupied West Bank refugee camps early this year amounts to war crimes and crimes against humanity, Human Rights Watch has said.
item.source:markdown: Israel's expulsion of tens of thousands of Palestinians from three Occupied West Bank refugee camps early this year amounts to war crimes and crimes against humanity, Human Rights Watch has said.

item.title: EU pushes back on US-backed peace plan for Ukraine
item.description: European countries have pushed back against a US-backed peace plan for Ukraine that sources said would require Kyiv to give up more land and partially disarm, conditions long seen by Ukraine's allies as tantamount to capitulation.
item.source:markdown: European countries have pushed back against a US-backed peace plan for Ukraine that sources said would require Kyiv to give up more land and partially disarm, conditions long seen by Ukraine's allies as tantamount to capitulation.

item.title: Zelensky ready to work with US on plan to end war
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has said he is ready to work with the US on a plan to end the war in Ukraine, and he expects to discuss it with US President Donald Trump in the coming days.
item.source:markdown: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has said he is ready to work with the US on a plan to end the war in Ukraine, and he expects to discuss it with US President Donald Trump in the coming days.

item.title: Trump to meet NYC mayor-elect Mamdani at White House on Friday
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump said he will meet New York City mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani at the White House on Friday in what would be the first meeting of the Republican leader with the democratic socialist who won this month's mayoral election.

item.title: Mamdani to meet President Trump in Washington
item.description: US President Donald Trump said he will host New York's mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani for a meeting tomorrow, after strongly criticising the 34-year-old self-described Democratic Socialist during his recent campaign.
item.source:markdown: US President Donald Trump said he will host New York's mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani for a meeting tomorrow, after strongly criticising the 34-year-old self-described Democratic Socialist during his recent campaign.

item.title: Why the U.S. Justice Department and Congress may battle over redaction of Epstein files
item.description: When it comes to the Epstein files, there are solid reasons to withold certain information from the public, experts say. However, there are also grey areas that could cause disputes between lawmakers and the U.S. Department of Justice, and which could frustrate those seeking as much information as possible about the case.
item.source:markdown:
![Attorney General Pam Bondi speaks with reporters during a news conference at the Department of Justice, Wednesday, Nov. 19, 2025, in Washington. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein)](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/aa232cf5-363a-4911-863f-0ae748a215a2,1763598554373/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C245%2C4698%2C2642%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
When it comes to the Epstein files, there are solid reasons to withold certain information from the public, experts say. However, there are also grey areas that could cause disputes between lawmakers and the U.S. Department of Justice, and which could frustrate those seeking as much information as possible about the case.

item.title: In the shadow of the Himalayas, this town is sinking, a casualty of the past and the present
item.description: Almost three years ago, hundreds of residents in Joshimath, India, were forced to leave after deep cracks appeared in the walls of some 800 homes because the ground was sinking around them. The town's location, climate change and heavy construction are being blamed.
item.source:markdown:
![Houses and other buildings are located at the bottom of a mountain range.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/3558d923-04f9-46d0-821c-3b469eaf4d93,1763588082114/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%281%2C0%2C4238%2C2383%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Almost three years ago, hundreds of residents in Joshimath, India, were forced to leave after deep cracks appeared in the walls of some 800 homes because the ground was sinking around them. The town's location, climate change and heavy construction are being blamed.

item.title: She lost 5 children during the war in Gaza — now she’s raising 36 grandkids in a tent
item.description: Reda Aliwa, 60, is caring for her 36 grandchildren in Gaza City after five of her own children were killed this September. Statistics suggest there are some 40,000 children in Gaza who’ve lost one or more parents, resulting in what one Palestinian organization has called “the largest orphan crisis in modern history.”
item.source:markdown:
![A woman in a black hijab sits in a dark tent as children play behind her. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b344396f-7c03-40c7-9b0a-b943e919b33f,1763611104438/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Reda Aliwa, 60, is caring for her 36 grandchildren in Gaza City after five of her own children were killed this September. Statistics suggest there are some 40,000 children in Gaza who’ve lost one or more parents, resulting in what one Palestinian organization has called “the largest orphan crisis in modern history.”

item.title: Olympic Truce: ‘Humanity can find common ground through sport’
item.description: Sport has always been more than a contest of strength or skill. item.title: Listening to others out of love: Age is no barrier for religious sisters
item.description:
Although many religious congregations in Europe face the challenge of aging members, the heart of their vocation remains unchanged: to serve those in need with love and dedication. item.source:markdown: A man who took part in the Dublin riots - looting cigarettes from a Gala store and helping gather rubbish which was later set on fire - has been jailed for two years.

item.title: A solid gold toilet called 'America' and reportedly worth millions, is up for auction
item.description: Art collectors have a chance Tuesday to buy one of the world's most lucrative latrines: a solid gold, fully functional toilet. The piece, by provocative Italian artist Maurizio Cattelan, goes up for auction Tuesday evening at Sotheby's in New York.

item.title: Tusk: Ukrainians working for Russia behind rail sabotage

item.title: Syria begins first public trial over deadly coastal violence
item.description:
Syria launches its first public trial over deadly clashes in March, during which pro-government fighters killed hundreds of members of the Alawite minority in their coastal homeland. The case is widely seen as a test of President Ahmed al-Sharaa’s promise of accountability.

Read all

item.title: ‘Parasocial’ is Cambridge Dictionary's word of the year
item.description: If you felt more excited for Taylor Swift’s engagement announcement earlier this year than you did for your friend or family member’s, you might relate to Cambridge Dictionary’s word of 2025: "parasocial," which describes having a one-sided connection with someone you do not know, such as a celebrity, a fictional character or an AI chatbot.
item.source:markdown:
![definitions of words are listed in alphabetical order running down a white page in a closeup of a dictionary](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/14cab21b-8fed-4434-8b5c-5fd9c99098ae,1763490594593/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C248%2C3000%2C1687%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
If you felt more excited for Taylor Swift’s engagement announcement earlier this year than you did for your friend or family member’s, you might relate to Cambridge Dictionary’s word of 2025: "parasocial," which describes having a one-sided connection with someone you do not know, such as a celebrity, a fictional character or an AI chatbot.

item.title: Israel hails Trump Gaza plan after UNSC vote
item.description: Israel has hailed US President Donald Trump's Gaza peace plan after its endorsement by the UN Security Council, as Hamas rejected the resolution which calls for the deployment of an international force in the Palestinian territory.

item.title: Restarting the Economy: (Still) time to rest - the Jubilee Year as the world's 'Sabbath'
item.description:
From 28 to 30 November, Castel Gandolfo will be host to 'Restarting the Economy', a global meeting promoted by The Economy of Francesco. The international event will be aimed at rethinking the economy in light of the Jubilee, focusing on social justice, care for the Earth, and freedom from debt.

Read all

item.title: Ghana’s Catholic Bishops outline pastoral priorities
item.description:
The Ghana Catholic Bishops’ Conference (GCBC) has concluded its 2025 annual plenary assembly held in the Diocese of Damongo, during which key pastoral priorities and national concerns for the coming years were outlined. The assembly took place from 7 to 14 November under the theme “A Synodal Church at the Service of Justice and Peace in Ghana.”

Read all

item.title: Gaza: After Security Council breakthrough, agencies highlight youngsters’ plight
item.description: As UN Secretary-General António Guterres hailed Monday’s Security Council resolution paving the way for a consolidated ceasefire via a temporary International Stabilization Force in Gaza, UN aid teams warned that many Palestinian children in the enclave are in no shape to endure another harsh winter.

item.title: Ending world hunger costs less than 1% of military spending
item.description: Ending hunger by 2030 would cost just $93 billion a year — well under one per cent of the $21.9 trillion spent on military budgets over the past decade, according to UN estimates.

item.title: Sheriffs identify Calgary girl who was swept into Pacific Ocean by California wave

item.title: FEMA acting chief out after just 6 months at helm of agency

item.title: Dozens of people die in DRC mine accident
item.description:
At least 32 people have been killed in southeastern Democratic Republic of Congo when a bridge at a copper and cobalt mine collapsed due to overcrowding. Enormous financial interests in the mineral-rich region have long fuelled strife and conflict, resulting in corruption, displacement and an acute humanitarian crisis.

item.title: On Brazil’s Combu Island, chocolate makers hold clues to climate action
item.description: Combu Island – Ilha do Combu in Portuguese – rises like a wall of living green from Brazil’s Guamá River. It is a testament to centuries of shared existence between the forest and its riverside communities. Here, cupuaçu, taperebá, pupunha, araçá and cacao are more than fruits; they are threads in the fabric of local culture, livelihoods and identity.
item.source:markdown: Combu Island – Ilha do Combu in Portuguese – rises like a wall of living green from Brazil’s Guamá River. It is a testament to centuries of shared existence between the forest and its riverside communities. Here, cupuaçu, taperebá, pupunha, araçá and cacao are more than fruits; they are threads in the fabric of local culture, livelihoods and identity.

item.title: COP30 enters its final stretch: urgency, ambition, and voices from the streets
item.description: The last week of COP30 has begun in Belém with a palpable sense of urgency. Ministers and senior officials are now stepping into the spotlight, as negotiations move from technical wrangling to political decision-making. The stakes? Nothing less than charting a credible path to climate justice in a world running out of time.

item.title: Flower of Srebrenica takes root at the United Nations
item.description: A 12-year-old boy and his grandmother cut the ribbon at UN Headquarters on Monday to inaugurate a flower-shaped memorial to the victims of the Srebrenica genocide – a permanent reminder of the 1995 massacre and the United Nation’s failure to stop it.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: US hails ‘historic and constructive resolution’ on Gaza
item.description: The Security Council has passed a US-backed resolution which will establish an international force to restore order in Gaza, protect civilians and open the way for large-scale aid and rebuilding. There were 13 votes for, none against – while Russia and China abstained amid concerns that Russia might veto the text. US ambassador Mike Waltz thanked ambassadors, hailing it as an “historic and constructive resolution” which charts a new course for the Middle East. Follow live below, check out full meetings coverage here, and UN News app users, follow here.
item.source:markdown: The Security Council has passed a US-backed resolution which will establish an international force to restore order in Gaza, protect civilians and open the way for large-scale aid and rebuilding. There were 13 votes for, none against – while Russia and China abstained amid concerns that Russia might veto the text. US ambassador Mike Waltz thanked ambassadors, hailing it as an “historic and constructive resolution” which charts a new course for the Middle East. item.title: Synod: Interim reports of Study Groups published
item.description:
Established by Pope Francis in March 2024, the Study Groups have delivered reports on the work carried out so far, starting from the conclusion of the Synod on Synodality. The deadline for delivering the final reports to Leo XIV has been set for 31 December. Among the topics covered are the digital mission, the role of women, ecumenism, polygamy, liturgy, the ministry of nuncios, and the selection of bishops.

item.title: Mexican government pursues second-shooter theory in 1994 political assassination that shook country
item.description: The March 23, 1994, death of Luis Donaldo Colosio, a reformer on the cusp of winning the Mexican presidency who promised a more just and democratic country, holds a space in the country's consciousness like the 1963 killing of President John F. item.title: Vatican returns Indigenous cultural items to Canada's Catholic bishops on a 'historic day'
item.description: A century-old Inuvialuit kayak once used for beluga and whale hunts, and 61 other cultural objects from First Nations, Métis and Inuit communities have long been held in Vatican Museums vaults. But the items will be returned to Canada on Dec. 6 after Pope Leo on Saturday gifted them to a delegation of Catholic bishops.
item.source:markdown:
![An old kayak](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/08d290ec-b8d2-48e0-b0cc-aab10062b316,1761052356002/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28241%2C0%2C938%2C527%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
A century-old Inuvialuit kayak once used for beluga and whale hunts, and 61 other cultural objects from First Nations, Métis and Inuit communities have long been held in Vatican Museums vaults. But the items will be returned to Canada on Dec. 6 after Pope Leo on Saturday gifted them to a delegation of Catholic bishops.

item.description: Mu’ayyad Ajjour and his neighbour Mohamed Zaida have searched every day among the ruins of a building, hoping to find the remains of five-year-old Masa, Ajjour's cousin, so they can give her a proper burial. item.title: Pope Leo XIV: ‘We can no longer tolerate structural injustices’
item.description:
A new book by Pope Leo XIV, “La forza del Vangelo: la fede cristiana in 10 parole,” includes a previously unpublished text by the Holy Father. Published by Libreria Editrice Vaticana and set to be released November 20, “La forza del Vangelo,” is an anthology of interventions and speeches by Pope Leo organized around key Christian themes.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
A new book by Pope Leo XIV, “La forza del Vangelo: la fede cristiana in 10 parole,” includes a previously unpublished text by the Holy Father. Published by Libreria Editrice Vaticana and set to be released November 20, “La forza del Vangelo,” is an anthology of interventions and speeches by Pope Leo organized around key Christian themes.

item.title: A glimpse at the just-released “Leo from Chicago”
item.description:
Here’s a first look at the Vatican’s newly released documentary Leo from Chicago, which explores the roots of Pope Leo XIV and offers never-before-seen footage of Robert Francis Prevost in his native United States. The film features in-depth interviews with his brothers, Louis and John Prevost, and reveals new personal details — including what he looks forward to most on Thanksgiving, and how even as a boy he was able to turn 'an unruly little mob into friends.'

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: From Haiti to Ethiopia: voices of climate displacement at COP30
item.description: Floods, heatwaves, droughts and storms are forcing millions from their homes every year. Most never cross a border; they remain internally displaced yet uprooted all the same. item.title: The hospital boats continuing Pope Francis' legacy in the Amazon

This is the testimony of Felipe, a volunteer doctor.

item.title: Taiwan evacuates residents trapped by flooding as tropical storm approaches
item.description: Taiwan evacuated more than 8,000 people from coastal and mountainous areas and closed schools ahead of the arrival of tropical storm Fung-wong. In Yilan County, rescue workers ferried people using boats and amphibious vehicles after torrential rains triggered severe flooding, and residents worked to clear debris and water from their homes.

item.description:
In a message to an international conference in Rome, Cardinal Pietro Parolin warns that humanity risks “its own extinction” if artificial life forms fail to respect human dignity, and he calls for interdisciplinary and multicultural cooperation to guide technology toward true human progress.

item.description: The UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and World Food Programme (WFP) warn of a major hunger emergency, with acute food insecurity set to worsen in 16 countries and territories between now and May 2026, putting millions of lives at risk.

item.title: ‘A wave of truth’: COP30 targets disinformation threat to climate action
item.description: Negotiators in Belém, Brazil, opened COP30 with a stark warning: the race to avert catastrophic global heating is being sabotaged by a surge of climate disinformation. The falsehoods, spreading faster than ever online, threaten to derail fragile progress on climate action.

In his catechesis, Pope Leo highlights the importance of fraternity in our lives and describes it as something "deeply human". He explains that even though today's wars, tensions, and conflicts make fraternity seem difficult, without it, "we would not be able to survive, grow, or learn."

item.title: French foreign minister, at G7 meeting in Canada, says U.S. boat strikes violate international law
item.description: During a G7 meeting in Ontario, France's foreign affairs minister said the deadly boat strikes in the Caribbean carried out by the United States since early September violate international law. Colombia, California's governor and the Washington Post also weighed in on the strikes on Tuesday — but Canada has been relatively silent on the U.S. actions.

item.title: Typhoon brings floods to Taiwan as thousands evacuated
item.description: Taiwan evacuated more than 8,300 people ahead of the arrival of a much weakened Typhoon Fung-wong that brought record downpours to the mountainous east coast and unleashed floods that rose neck-high in places.

item.title: U.S. tourism faces $5.7B US loss as Canadians continue to stay home
item.description: Many Canadians continue to boycott travel to the United States, and the U.S. economy is paying the price. A U.S. Travel Association report forecasts a 3.2 per cent decline in international tourism spending in the country for 2025, a loss of $5.7 billion US compared to the previous year.

Many Canadians continue to boycott travel to the United States, and the U.S. economy is paying the price. A U.S. Travel Association report forecasts a 3.2 per cent decline in international tourism spending in the country for 2025, a loss of $5.7 billion US compared to the previous year.

item.title: Swedish king’s visit highlights growing Canadian interest in Saab military aircraft
item.description: A few days before the federal budget was tabled, the CEO of Swedish industrial giant Saab flew to Ottawa to meet with the country's top bureaucrat, fuelling the sense a deal is brewing between the Canadian government and the military manufacturer. item.title: We have much to learn from our persecuted brothers and sisters in Africa
item.description:
Over the weekend, Pope Leo XIV speaking during the Saturday Jubilee Audience on 8 November 2025, in Saint Peter Square, reflected on the life of Blessed Isidore Bakanja, a young Congolese martyr. The testimony of Bakanja, “reminds us that we have much to learn from our persecuted brothers and sisters in Africa,” said Pope Leo XIV.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa death toll rises to 45 in Jamaica, with 15 others still missing
item.description: The number of confirmed deaths from Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica rose to 45, with 15 other people missing, authorities said Tuesday. The death toll is expected to rise, with officials still trying to reach two towns that remain cut off since the catastrophic Category 5 storm made landfall in western Jamaica on Oct. 28.
item.source:markdown:
![People standing amid wreckage](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/684fb96c-51dd-428f-b465-26658ebaa992,1762888277420/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C237%2C4552%2C2560%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The number of confirmed deaths from Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica rose to 45, with 15 other people missing, authorities said Tuesday. The death toll is expected to rise, with officials still trying to reach two towns that remain cut off since the catastrophic Category 5 storm made landfall in western Jamaica on Oct. 28.

item.title: Keeping cool on a hotter planet: COP30 pushes for sustainable cooling and AI innovation
item.description: As the planet heats up, so does the race for smarter, cleaner technology. item.title: From pledges to action: Leaders push for faster climate progress at COP30
item.description: COP30 opened in Belém on Monday with a clear message: the era of half-measures is over. Climate change is here, devastating communities and driving up costs, but solutions are within reach. Clean energy is surging, resilience saves lives, and cooperation can still bend the curve further.

item.title: Gazans continue heading home as ‘fragile ceasefire’ holds
item.description: A month into the ceasefire in Gaza, families continue to slowly head back to their former homes and communities wherever access is allowed, the UN agency that assists Palestine refugees, UNRWA, said on Monday.

item.title: Tanzania: Church prays and hopes for reconciliation and peace
item.description:
As street protests affect Tanzania, the Archdiocese of Mbeya has been among the hardest hit, with more than a hundred victims. Fr. Valerio Mwandanji, parish priest of St. Matthew the Apostle Church, says a Mass was celebrated on 9 November “to remember those who lost their lives during the demonstrations. The people are calling for change.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: U.S. Supreme Court rejects bid to overturn same-sex marriage ruling
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court rejected on Monday a bid by a former Kentucky county official to overturn its landmark 2015 ruling legalizing same-sex marriage nationwide, as the justices steered clear of the contentious case some 3-1/2 years after its conservative majority reversed abortion rights.

item.title: 8 people dead in car explosion near Red Fort in New Delhi

item.title: Hall of Famer and former Raptors coach Lenny Wilkens dies at 88
item.description: Lenny Wilkens, a three-time inductee into the Basketball Hall of Fame who was enshrined as both a player and a coach, has died, his family said Sunday. He was 88. The family said Wilkens was surrounded by loved ones when he died and did not immediately release a cause of death.

item.title: Trump administration wants U.S. states to 'undo' full payouts of food aid benefits
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration is demanding states "undo" full SNAP food benefits paid out under judges' orders over the past week, now that the U.S. Supreme Court has stayed those rulings — marking the latest swing in a seesawing legal battle over the anti-hunger program used by 42 million Americans.

item.title: Pope at Angelus: We are Christ's Church meant to joyfully walk with Him
item.description:
During his weekly Angelus address, Pope Leo XIV reminds the faithful that "the true sanctuary of God is Christ" who is "the only mediator of salvation, the only Redeemer, the One who, by uniting Himself with our humanity, and transforming us with His love, represents the door that opens wide for us and leads us to the Father."

Read all

item.title: Pope: The Church is a ‘construction site’ for a community to be built without haste
item.description:
Celebrating Mass on the occasion of the Dedication of the Basilica of St John Lateran, Pope Leo XIV reflects on the Church, urging the faithful to be ‘free from the criteria of the world, which too often demands immediate results because it does not know the wisdom of waiting’. ‘Jesus changes us and calls us to work in God's great construction site, wisely shaping us according to His plans for salvation.’ ‘In Rome,’ says the Pope, ‘there is a great good that grows’ beyond the hardships.

Read all

item.title: Impact of tracker mortgage scandal not consigned to past
item.description:
It's the biggest consumer overcharging scandal in the history of the State which cost the banks in excess of €1 billion in fines and redress to customers.

item.title: Six months with Pope Leo XIV: A united and open Church, a sign of peace for a world wounded by hatred
item.description:
There is a common thread running through the magisterium of the new Pope: he has proposed a model of Christian community, missionary in nature, where communion is lived, and which is therefore capable of serving all, starting with the least; a community committed to fostering dialogue and peace. A Church that does not “lean” on the powerful nor confuse mission with religious marketing, but knows how to be leaven because it reflects the light of Another.

Read all

item.title: Niagara family, mayor call for hotelier Jimmy Lai's release from Hong Kong prison as G7 ministers set to meet
item.description: As G7 foreign ministers prepare to meet in Ontario's Niagara Region, family of hotel owner Jimmy Lai and Niagara-on-the-Lake’s lord mayor are calling for the pro-democracy activist's release from a Hong Kong prison. Pope Leo XIV urges participants in the “Builders AI Forum” to ensure that artificial intelligence serves human dignity, justice, and the common good, and notes that the development of ethical technology must be a shared, ecclesial mission reflecting God the Creator’s design: “intelligent, relational, and guided by love.”

item.title: Trump administration fights court ruling to pay food assistance to 42 million amid shutdown

item.description: More than 18,000 oysters have been deployed in Dún Laoghaire harbour in Dublin, in the next phase of an initiative to reintroduce the shellfish to Dublin Bay over 200 years after they became extinct from the area.

item.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi brings rain and destruction to Vietnam as death toll nears 190 in Philippines
item.description: At least five people died in Vietnam after Typhoon Kalmaegi pummelled coastal regions with destructive winds and heavy rain, officials said on Friday, following the storm's deadly passage through the Philippines where it killed at least 188 people.

At least five people died in Vietnam after Typhoon Kalmaegi pummelled coastal regions with destructive winds and heavy rain, officials said on Friday, following the storm's deadly passage through the Philippines where it killed at least 188 people.

item.title: Amid rising violence, Nigeria rejects Trump’s claim of targeted Christian persecution
item.description: This week, President Trump threatened to send the U.S. military into Nigeria for not doing enough to protect Christians. For years, Nigeria has struggled to curtail violence across the country, from international terrorist groups to disputes between farmers and herders. But now, its leadership must face threats from both its internal adversaries and the White House. Nick Schifrin reports. PBS News is supported by - https://www.pbs.org/newshour/about/funders. item.title: Pope Leo remembers Cardinal Duka as 'fearless proclaimer of the Gospel'
item.description:
In a telegram of condolences, Pope Leo XIV praises the late Cardinal Dominik Duka, O.P., Archbishop emeritus of Prague, who passed away on Tuesday at age 82, saying, "I remember with admiration his courage during the time of persecution, when, deprived of his freedom, he did not falter in his adherence to Christ and to the Church."

item.title: Afghanistan: Opium cultivation drops sharply, but regional trafficking rises

item.title: New Brazil-led fund aims to put forest protection at the heart of climate action
item.description: Tropical forests, vital allies in the fight against climate breakdown, are vanishing at an alarming rate. On Thursday, in a bid to help reverse this trend, Brazil launched a new initiative at a summit of world leaders in Belém, the gateway to the Amazon.

item.title: Mary Ward’s vision fulfilled as two congregations merge
item.description:
Venerable Mary Ward, foundress of the spiritual family that would become the Congregation of Jesus (CJ) and the Institute of the Blessed Virgin Mary (IBVM, the Loreto Sisters), long desired that her followers be one body. That vision has effectively been realized this week, as the two congregations, present in over 40 countries, are now united as a single institute.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Venerable Mary Ward, foundress of the spiritual family that would become the Congregation of Jesus (CJ) and the Institute of the Blessed Virgin Mary (IBVM, the Loreto Sisters), long desired that her followers be one body. That vision has effectively been realized this week, as the two congregations, present in over 40 countries, are now united as a single institute.

item.title: U.S. government shutdown is now the longest in history

item.title: At least 100 dead after typhoon hits Philippines
item.description: The death toll from Typhoon Kalmaegi in the Philippines has risen above 100 as the devastating impact on hard-hit Cebu province became clearer after the worst flooding in recent memory.
item.source:markdown: The death toll from Typhoon Kalmaegi in the Philippines has risen above 100 as the devastating impact on hard-hit Cebu province became clearer after the worst flooding in recent memory.

item.title: EU countries agree deal on 2040 climate target
item.description: EU environment ministers have reached agreement on the bloc's 2040 climate target following all-night negotiations in Brussels.
item.source:markdown: EU environment ministers have reached agreement on the bloc's 2040 climate target following all-night negotiations in Brussels.

item.title: Trump's claims of Christian persecution in Nigeria bump up against facts
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump's threats to go "guns-a-blazing" into Nigeria over what he claims to be deadly persecution of Christians are prompting pushback in the West African nation.

![Closeup photo of Donald Trump](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/6bcacd57-a1f1-4c2d-b096-f6abc5736d4b,1762280409465/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C388%2C5484%2C3084%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: This Texas county turned Republican for 1st time in over a century. A year on, voters say they have no regrets
item.description: CBC News recently travelled to Starr County, Texas, to get a better sense of how voters feel one year after Donald Trump returned to the White House. Trump flipped this county in 2024, becoming the first Republican presidential nominee to win it in 132 years — though residents are divided on his policies.
item.source:markdown:
![Three people eat at a restaurant table while speaking to a reporter.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/1b9e5d08-e8e4-4928-a625-cf5641e61c26,1762292458441/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C334%2C4032%2C2268%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
CBC News recently travelled to Starr County, Texas, to get a better sense of how voters feel one year after Donald Trump returned to the White House. Trump flipped this county in 2024, becoming the first Republican presidential nominee to win it in 132 years — though residents are divided on his policies.

item.title: 11 dead in Bosnia nursing home fire
item.description: Eleven people were killed and around 30 injured in a fire that broke out in a nursing home in northeastern Bosnia, police have said.

item.title: Climate projects too small to secure funding, says report
item.description: Finance for climate adaptation projects is below what is required to address the escalating risks posed by climate change, according to a new report.

item.title: New action plan to strengthen collective bargaining
item.description: The Government has launched an action plan to promote collective bargaining.

item.title: Audit finds gaps in access to beds in stroke units
item.description: A new audit on stroke care in Ireland has highlighted persistent gaps in access to beds in dedicated stroke units and specialist multi-disciplinary staffing, which are central to best practice.
item.source:markdown: A new audit on stroke care in Ireland has highlighted persistent gaps in access to beds in dedicated stroke units and specialist multi-disciplinary staffing, which are central to best practice.

item.title: At least 7 dead, 11 injured in UPS cargo plane crash
item.description: Seven people were killed and 11 others injured after a UPS cargo plane crashed shortly after take-off from the international airport in Louisville in the US state of Kentucky.
item.source:markdown: Seven people were killed and 11 others injured after a UPS cargo plane crashed shortly after take-off from the international airport in Louisville in the US state of Kentucky.

item.title: Brussels flights halted after suspected drone sightings
item.description: Flights were suspended at the main airport in Belgium's capital after suspected drone sightings, a Brussels Airport spokesman said.

item.title: Pope: ‘Spiritual rights’ of migrant detainees must be respected
item.description:
In remarks to journalists in Castel Gandolfo, Pope Leo calls for “deep reflection” on the treatment of migrants in the United States, urges "dialogue" between the US and Venezuela, warns that the Israel-Hamas peace deal is "very fragile", and expresses his hope that the trial of ex-Jesuit Marko Rupnik will "bring clarity and justice for everyone involved".

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In remarks to journalists in Castel Gandolfo, Pope Leo calls for “deep reflection” on the treatment of migrants in the United States, urges "dialogue" between the US and Venezuela, warns that the Israel-Hamas peace deal is "very fragile", and expresses his hope that the trial of ex-Jesuit Marko Rupnik will "bring clarity and justice for everyone involved".
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-11/pope-us-migrants-spiritual-rights-venezuela-gaza-work-rupnik.html)

item.title: Child among at least 12 killed in UPS plane crash in Kentucky
item.description: A UPS cargo plane's left wing caught fire and an engine fell off just before it crashed and exploded after takeoff in Kentucky, a federal investigator said Wednesday, offering the first official details about a disaster that killed at least 12 people, including a child.
item.source:markdown:
![Smoke and flames visible from a distance](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/8b1605bf-75b0-4997-84a0-a741caa93843,1762305779080/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C430%2C8256%2C4644%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
A UPS cargo plane's left wing caught fire and an engine fell off just before it crashed and exploded after takeoff in Kentucky, a federal investigator said Wednesday, offering the first official details about a disaster that killed at least 12 people, including a child.

item.title: Bird flu outbreak at commercial turkey flock in Carlow

item.title: Meat plant worker gets €20k for maternity discrimination

Archbishop Nkea was in Rome recently, leading over 100 “Pilgrims of Hope" visiting Rome and other holy sites for the 2025 Jubilee of Hope. The pilgrimage, which started on 24 October, conclude

item.title: Restarting the Economy: Rethinking Economics in the Light of the Jubilee
item.description:

item.title: World leaders adopt Doha declaration to boost efforts on social development

item.title: Around 224 million women still don’t access family planning
item.description: Since 1990, the number of people using modern contraception methods has doubled globally but despite this, nearly 224 million women in mainly developing regions still do not use safe and effective family planning methods, according to the UN sexual and reproductive health agency, UNFPA.
item.source:markdown: Since 1990, the number of people using modern contraception methods has doubled globally but despite this, nearly 224 million women in mainly developing regions still do not use safe and effective family planning methods, according to the UN sexual and reproductive health agency, UNFPA.

item.title: Syria’s future under threat from acute funding shortages
item.description: Hopes for a peaceful future in post-war Syria are at risk as funding for basic services dries up, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: Hopes for a peaceful future in post-war Syria are at risk as funding for basic services dries up, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

item.title: New climate pledges do little to correct global warming projection, UN warns
item.description: Available new climate pledges by governments have only slightly lowered global temperature rise over the course of this century, leaving the world on the path to a serious escalation of climate risks and damages.
item.source:markdown: Available new climate pledges by governments have only slightly lowered global temperature rise over the course of this century, leaving the world on the path to a serious escalation of climate risks and damages.

item.title: Gaza: Aid teams race to push back hunger; one million food parcels delivered
item.description: Food is slowly returning to the shelves in Gaza but supplies are still desperately inadequate, UN humanitarians said on Tuesday, as they issued fresh calls for wider access and continued financial support.
item.source:markdown: Food is slowly returning to the shelves in Gaza but supplies are still desperately inadequate, UN humanitarians said on Tuesday, as they issued fresh calls for wider access and continued financial support.

item.title: Potential Gaza stabilization force must have Security Council approval: Guterres
item.description: Any transition in Gaza must uphold unity with the West Bank and a two-State solution between Israelis and Palestinians, the UN Secretary-General said in Doha on Tuesday.
item.source:markdown: Any transition in Gaza must uphold unity with the West Bank and a two-State solution between Israelis and Palestinians, the UN Secretary-General said in Doha on Tuesday.

item.title: Doha: World Summit opens with pledge to speed social progress
item.description: The Second World Summit for Social Development opened in Doha on Tuesday with the adoption of the Doha Political Declaration – a consensus pledge to accelerate action on poverty eradication, decent work and social inclusion, and to put the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) back on track.
item.source:markdown: The Second World Summit for Social Development opened in Doha on Tuesday with the adoption of the Doha Political Declaration – a consensus pledge to accelerate action on poverty eradication, decent work and social inclusion, and to put the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) back on track.

item.title: Doha Social Summit: Path to fairer societies begins in the classroom
item.description: Education took centre stage on the opening day of the Second World Summit for Social Development in Doha, where leaders, educators and youth advocates underscored that learning is the foundation of inclusive and resilient societies.
item.source:markdown: Education took centre stage on the opening day of the Second World Summit for Social Development in Doha, where leaders, educators and youth advocates underscored that learning is the foundation of inclusive and resilient societies.

item.title: World News in Brief: Settler attacks in the West Bank, Madagascar hunger crisis, obesity in Europe
item.description: The UN humanitarian relief chief, Tom Fletcher, has sounded the alarm over rising violence in the occupied West Bank, where attacks by Israeli settlers on Palestinians and their property continue to escalate.
item.source:markdown: The UN humanitarian relief chief, Tom Fletcher, has sounded the alarm over rising violence in the occupied West Bank, where attacks by Israeli settlers on Palestinians and their property continue to escalate.

item.title: Half of Jamaica’s population reeling from Hurricane Melissa
item.description: More than 1.5 million Jamaicans have been impacted by the devastation resulting from Hurricane Melissa, many losing their homes and livelihoods.
item.source:markdown: More than 1.5 million Jamaicans have been impacted by the devastation resulting from Hurricane Melissa, many losing their homes and livelihoods.

item.title: Revealed: The fake letters and 'miracle cure' behind Carey's scam
item.description: Prime Time has obtained ten forged medical letters at the heart of DJ Carey's cancer scam, for which he was jailed for five and a half years yesterday.
item.source:markdown: Prime Time has obtained ten forged medical letters at the heart of DJ Carey's cancer scam, for which he was jailed for five and a half years yesterday.

item.title: Former US vice president Dick Cheney dies aged 84
item.description: Dick Cheney, arguably one of the most powerful vice president in US history as George W. Bush's number two during the 11 September 2001 attacks, has died aged 84.
item.source:markdown: Dick Cheney, arguably one of the most powerful vice president in US history as George W. Bush's number two during the 11 September 2001 attacks, has died aged 84.

item.title: Shein vows to cooperate with France in sex doll inquiry
item.description: Online retailer Shein has pledged to "cooperate fully" with French judicial authorities after an uproar over it selling childlike sex dolls, and said it was prepared to disclose the names of people who bought them.
item.source:markdown: Online retailer Shein has pledged to "cooperate fully" with French judicial authorities after an uproar over it selling childlike sex dolls, and said it was prepared to disclose the names of people who bought them.

item.title: Win or lose at the Supreme Court, Trump has other tariff tools at his disposal
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court takes on a major case on Wednesday when it decides if President Donald Trump has the authority to use a law usually cited in emergencies for the imposition of tariffs on other countries. While they may not be as blunt as the law Trump has cited, there are a handful of other laws the president can cite to utilize tariffs for leverage and revenue.
item.source:markdown:
![An older cleanshaven blonde-haired man wearing a suit and yellow tie is shown speaking in closeup.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/0f6713bc-9fe6-448a-894e-0ce85d246f66,1762269509261/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C7179%2C4038%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The U.S. Supreme Court takes on a major case on Wednesday when it decides if President Donald Trump has the authority to use a law usually cited in emergencies for the imposition of tariffs on other countries. While they may not be as blunt as the law Trump has cited, there are a handful of other laws the president can cite to utilize tariffs for leverage and revenue.

item.title: Dundalk's kit supplier begins legal action over debt
item.description: Kit supplier Playr-Fit have begun legal proceedings against Dundalk FC over an unpaid debt of €130,000, claiming they have also broken an agreement which relates to the issuing of a licence to compete in the League of Ireland last year.
item.source:markdown: Kit supplier Playr-Fit have begun legal proceedings against Dundalk FC over an unpaid debt of €130,000, claiming they have also broken an agreement which relates to the issuing of a licence to compete in the League of Ireland last year.

item.title: COP30 in Brazil: The Amazon nears the “point of no return”
item.description:
The world’s largest tropical rainforest will host its first COP in Belém, Brazil — a symbolic choice highlighting the Amazon’s crucial role in safeguarding global biodiversity and the planet’s climate. Researcher Jhan-Carlo Espinoza of France’s Institute of Research for Development (IRD) and member of the Science Panel for the Amazon, takes stock of the situation.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The world’s largest tropical rainforest will host its first COP in Belém, Brazil — a symbolic choice highlighting the Amazon’s crucial role in safeguarding global biodiversity and the planet’s climate. Researcher Jhan-Carlo Espinoza of France’s Institute of Research for Development (IRD) and member of the Science Panel for the Amazon, takes stock of the situation.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/world/news/2025-11/cop30-in-brazil-the-amazon-nears-the-point-of-no-return.html)

item.title: At least 26 dead after Typhoon Kalmaegi barrels through Philippines
item.description: Typhoon Kalmaegi has left at least 26 people dead in the Philippines, mostly in flooding set off by the storm, which barrelled across the central part of the country on Tuesday, disaster response officials said.

![Two cars are stacked on top of each other amid houses and rubble and mud. A man climbs over some rubble](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/e328b39d-ad96-4748-a294-faa8ae8f2560,1762264725583/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1600%2C900%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Typhoon Kalmaegi has left at least 26 people dead in the Philippines, mostly in flooding set off by the storm, which barrelled across the central part of the country on Tuesday, disaster response officials said.

The document of the Dicastery for the Doctrine of the Faith, approved by Pope Leo XIV, offers clarifications on titles applied to the Blessed Virgin Mary, and calls for special attention to the use of the expression, “Mediatrix of all graces.”

item.title: 10 years after the UN climate pact, what did it actually do?
item.description: In 2015, nearly 200 countries adopted the Paris Agreement, the first global pact to fight climate change. Here's a comparison of then and now — in terms of the state of the climate, the way we live and our technologies, our laws and where we're putting our money.

item.title: Millions in US to get reduced food aid during shutdown

item.title: Cuban government stealing wages from its citizens in Canada, say ex-workers
item.description: Former workers of a joint venture between the government of Cuba and Canadian mining company Sherritt International say they were victims of a wage confiscation scheme that left them to live on just a fraction of their nominal salaries. They also say they were forced to attend Communist Party meetings and provide reports on all interactions with their Canadian colleagues.
item.source:markdown:

Former workers of a joint venture between the government of Cuba and Canadian mining company Sherritt International say they were victims of a wage confiscation scheme that left them to live on just a fraction of their nominal salaries. They also say they were forced to attend Communist Party meetings and provide reports on all interactions with their Canadian colleagues.

item.title: China’s spy joke with South Korea that sounded like a warning | About That
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping gifted South Korean President Lee Jae Myung a pair of smartphones, jokingly telling him to 'check if there's a backdoor' — referring to the risk of unauthorized bypassing of security controls. Andrew Chang breaks down the layers of Xi's comment to better understand what may have been hidden behind the humour. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images
item.source:markdown:
![Chinese President Xi Jinping gives two cellphones to South Korean President Lee Jae Myung in Gyeongju, South Korea.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/f03eab10-506e-4cbd-b7b5-bec96d94d564,1762217012625/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1468%2C825%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Chinese President Xi Jinping gifted South Korean President Lee Jae Myung a pair of smartphones, jokingly telling him to 'check if there's a backdoor' — referring to the risk of unauthorized bypassing of security controls. Andrew Chang breaks down the layers of Xi's comment to better understand what may have been hidden behind the humour.
Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

item.title: Jamaicans rush to ready island for busy tourism season in wake of Hurricane Melissa

item.title: Trump administration will partially restore food benefit funding after judges’ ruling
item.description: The Trump administration says it will restart the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, but will only pay half the amount people usually get. The move comes after two federal judges ruled that freezing payments for the U.S.'s biggest anti-hunger program is unlawful.

item.title: FAO warns of ‘silent crisis’ as land degradation threatens billions

item.title: UN agencies on hand as deadly new quake hits northern Afghanistan
item.description: UN teams rushed to northern Afghanistan on Monday after a powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck overnight, just two months after a massive quake devastated the east of the country. Details are still emerging from the latest emergency where initial reports indicate at least 20 people have been killed and hundreds injured.
item.source:markdown: UN teams rushed to northern Afghanistan on Monday after a powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck overnight, just two months after a massive quake devastated the east of the country. item.title: Pope on All Souls' Day: God has opened for us the way to eternal life
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV presides over the Mass for the Commemoration of All the Faithful Departed at Rome’s Monumental Verano Cemetery. He recalls that "Christian faith, founded upon Christ’s Paschal mystery, helps us to experience our memories as more than just a recollection of the past but also, and above all, as hope for the future.” Later, he visited the crypt of Saint Peter's Basilica to pray for the deceased Popes.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Pope Leo XIV presides over the Mass for the Commemoration of All the Faithful Departed at Rome’s Monumental Verano Cemetery. He recalls that "Christian faith, founded upon Christ’s Paschal mystery, helps us to experience our memories as more than just a recollection of the past but also, and above all, as hope for the future.” Later, he visited the crypt of Saint Peter's Basilica to pray for the deceased Popes.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-11/pope-on-all-souls-day-god-has-opened-way-to-eternal-life.html)

item.title: Size of spoiled vote the elephant in the room of election
item.description: A total of 213,738 people spoiled their vote in the recent Presidential Election, and questions remain as to why so many people chose to do so.
item.source:markdown: A total of 213,738 people spoiled their vote in the recent Presidential Election, and questions remain as to why so many people chose to do so.

item.title: China's Xi meets South Korean leader at APEC summit
item.description: Chinese leader Xi Jinping met his South Korean counterpart Lee Jae Myung, after taking centre stage at an Asian summit in the wake of US President Donald Trump's departure.
item.source:markdown: Chinese leader Xi Jinping met his South Korean counterpart Lee Jae Myung, after taking centre stage at an Asian summit in the wake of US President Donald Trump's departure.

item.title: Royal family banishes Andrew, but controversy will linger
item.description: Ever since the publication of the late Virginia Giuffre's posthumous memoir, there has been a growing sense that King Charles would have to take tougher action against his younger brother. It was a case of when, not if the King would take action.
item.source:markdown: Ever since the publication of the late Virginia Giuffre's posthumous memoir, there has been a growing sense that King Charles would have to take tougher action against his younger brother. It was a case of when, not if the King would take action.

item.title: 'There's no due process': ICU nurse, army veteran among U.S. citizens caught in ICE dragnet
item.description: Two U.S. citizens whose forceful arrests by ICE were caught on video say federal agents violated their constitutional rights. As backlash against the administration's escalating immigration raids grows, more than 170 U.S. citizens have been detained by immigration officers since Trump reclaimed the presidency.
item.source:markdown:
![A composite image showing a nurse with tattoos on her arm on the left and a young soldier in a T-shirt on the right.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/cd7e40d9-3742-4a36-8009-ccacb0615bc1,1761930960169/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Two U.S. citizens whose forceful arrests by ICE were caught on video say federal agents violated their constitutional rights. As backlash against the administration's escalating immigration raids grows, more than 170 U.S. citizens have been detained by immigration officers since Trump reclaimed the presidency.

item.title: Is the world back to testing nuclear weapons? Here are the facts
item.description: For more than 30 years, major nuclear powers have refrained from testing nuclear bombs. But that streak may soon be over as Russia and the U.S. conduct missile tests and threaten to resume explosions of the most powerful weapons ever devised.
item.source:markdown:
![A white line streaks across the dark sky in an arc](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/8590ac61-0154-464c-8e99-ce851404310c,1761938541767/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C246%2C5211%2C2931%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
For more than 30 years, major nuclear powers have refrained from testing nuclear bombs. But that streak may soon be over as Russia and the U.S. conduct missile tests and threaten to resume explosions of the most powerful weapons ever devised.

item.title: How much of a role did climate change play with Hurricane Melissa?
item.description: Millions of people across the Caribbean are trying to deal with the devastating effects of Hurricane Melissa, which tore through the region this week, slamming into Jamaica as a Category 5 storm. Now, several groups have done a rapid analysis to determine what role climate change could have played.
item.source:markdown:
![Part of the Caribbean is seen from a satellite along with Florida and other islands while a big circular cloud sits over Jamaica.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/fa41c082-3508-4705-b172-cf746f756752,1761854107929/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C186%2C2805%2C1577%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Millions of people across the Caribbean are trying to deal with the devastating effects of Hurricane Melissa, which tore through the region this week, slamming into Jamaica as a Category 5 storm. Now, several groups have done a rapid analysis to determine what role climate change could have played.

item.title: Withholding the dead has long been a bargaining tactic for Israel and Hamas
item.description: The practice of withholding the dead lives on both sides of the Israeli-Hamas war, a cruel bargaining tactic not exclusive to this latest Gaza conflict.
item.source:markdown:
![People in black clothing carry a white bag on a stretcher. ](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b87d4260-0f61-4c77-ba08-7b2e0af606b7,1761779010656/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C107%2C2612%2C1469%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The practice of withholding the dead lives on both sides of the Israeli-Hamas war, a cruel bargaining tactic not exclusive to this latest Gaza conflict.

item.title: My country has been 'ripped apart,' Jamaican farm worker says as people in Niagara call out for help
item.description: Rohan Thompson was keeping a close eye on Melissa from St. Catharines, Ont., where he works as a temporary farm worker, as the Category 5 hurricane approached his homeland earlier this week.
item.source:markdown:
![Man and woman sitting at a table with a map of Jamaica and disaster relief supplies](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/fb05a246-c7d8-4fef-88e9-d8a3a0c3b574,1762002420722/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C4154%2C2336%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Rohan Thompson was keeping a close eye on Melissa from St. Catharines, Ont., where he works as a temporary farm worker, as the Category 5 hurricane approached his homeland earlier this week.

item.title: Flights resume at Berlin airport after drone scare
item.description: Flights were suspended for almost two hours at Berlin Brandenburg Airport due to sightings of unidentified drones, the latest in a series of similar scares across Europe.
item.source:markdown: Flights were suspended for almost two hours at Berlin Brandenburg Airport due to sightings of unidentified drones, the latest in a series of similar scares across Europe.

item.title: Minister warns of 'serious consequences' following fire
item.description: The Minister for Justice has warned of "serious consequences" after a fire at a building accommodating people applying for International Protection.
item.source:markdown: The Minister for Justice has warned of "serious consequences" after a fire at a building accommodating people applying for International Protection.

item.title: IPAS centre fire started deliberately, say gardaí
item.description: A fire at a building accommodating people applying for International Protection in Drogheda was started deliberately, gardaí have confirmed.
item.source:markdown: A fire at a building accommodating people applying for International Protection in Drogheda was started deliberately, gardaí have confirmed.
